Waggin' Tails Adoption Information:  Waggin' Tails Dog Rescue has a standard adoption fee of $225 for adult dogs.  Different adoption fees apply for older dogs, small breeds and puppies - $125 for senior dogs (9 years +) , $275 for small breed dogs and $250 for puppies, plus a $50 deposit which is returned upon proof of spay/neuter.  Our adoption process includes an application, vet reference checks, and a home visit. Waggin' Tails Dog Rescue does not have a shelter facility.  All of our dogs are fostered in private homes.  To meet a dog in person, please see our event calendar on our website at www.waggintailsdogrescue.org for the latest information.  Arrangements can be made to meet our rescue dogs outside of Saturday adoption events after an approved application is submitted.  This application does not imply an obligation to adopt by the applicant or by the rescue group. Stacy was found on the side of the street one day in April. I went out to help save her and found her laying there helpless. We got her to emergency where we got her comfortable. She was later transported to port Huron where she had her broken hips fixed. The accident did leave her with a partial paralyzed front paw. She does still use it to pull herself up. She is such a love bug and very happy just to have someone to lay with. She is great with men, kids, and woman. She just isn't great with other animals. She does like my male pit but she is kept separate with my other dogs. Lacy has come so far from last April. She is happy, healthy and strong. Her bad paw doesn't get in her way of getting where she wants to go. She is gentle when taking food from you hand. PLEASE CONTACT Jensq7665@aol.com FOR MORE INFORMATION

Nadia is a beautiful three year old that was rescued from euthanasia. Her previous owner adopted her along with her littermate at six weeks of age. After 2 years her sister was put to sleep because he showed signs of food aggression. Within 3 weeks of her death her old owner got another puppy. It was only a matter of time, before there were some fights, and because she was larger it was decided that Nadia would be put to sleep. That was when a rescurer stepped in and rescued her from certain death. Nadia is house trained, can sit and shake hands. She loves to play with her beloved toys. She loves to cuddle and give kisses. She does NOT do well with other animals or small children. She does well on a leash but would prefer a fenced in yard. She needs professional nail trimmings, and I am not sure how she would do with a bath. She is up to date on her vaccinations, and she is a good girl. She is a good girl just waiting for the good life. If anyone is interested in adopting or properly fostering Nadia please contact me at tahrahetzer@yahoo.com

SPONSORED FEE: Kasey's Adoption Fee has been sponsored.

Hi, my name is Kasey. I came into my foster home emaciated, full of parasites, with an extremely bad UTI. It's taken me awhile to get back to health, but I'm doing so much better! We don't know how long I actually had a UTI that was left untreated, but due to this, I do leak urine. We are currently still working along side the vet to see if this will be a life long issue.

I was very loving and friendly when I came into my foster home, but I was very withdrawn. I have come so far! I am still skittish because of some things that must have happened to me in my past. I don't care for garbage trucks, or thunder, and when my 10 year old human brother gets rowdy with his toy weapons and such, I get very nervous. However, I have never growled or attempted to bite anyone. I just go hide by my foster Mom when I get nervous or scared.

I love to play with my foster sister who is an Airedale Terrier. We play great together and have a lot of fun! We are great buddies! I would love a home with a very friendly buddy that gets along with everyone as I do.

I really do need a fenced yard. I do have greyhound in me, and if I got loose, I would probably make it very far away in a short time! I walk pretty well on a leash, and I will go potty on leash. I also need to have a martingale collar kept on me, because like a greyhound, I can slip a collar easily. My neck is wider than my head.

I didn't really care for the crate for a long time. Maybe this was because of being stuck in the cage at animal control. My foster Mom has worked with me, and I am much better. I am crated when the family leaves the house. At night, I will sleep on my dog bed, on the bedroom floor all night long with no problems.

I am very smart! I already knew how to sit,lay down, and shake. My foster Mom says that someone could probably train me to do much more!

I have MANY greyhound traits! If you've ever been around a greyhound, when you meet me, you'll see exactly what I mean! My Mom thinks my most prominent Belgian Malinois trait is my bond to one person in the home. Which is my foster Mom! Don't get me wrong, I love everyone else too, she just happens to be my favorite! Oh, and I have a big, tuff bark! I will surely scare someone away if you need me to! I do like to be a bit bossy to my Airedale sister sometimes. If she starts barking, I will go put her in her place. I sound like I'm being mean to her, but I don't hurt her, I just try to tell her to knock it off! Luckily, she's as friendly as she is, and just tries to ignore me. Mom gets after me when I do this, and I'm getting a bit better with it.

I don't think I would like a very loud and busy house. When it gets like that here sometimes, I get very nervous and worried. Mom thinks that maybe I was in a home with a lot of fighting and violence. Sometimes I'm not sure if people are playing or fighting, and it makes me very scared. Mom reassures me that everything is OK, and makes everyone calm down.

Oh, I forgot to mention. Mom stays at home! I'm lucky because now that my big sister is off to college, and my 10 year old brother is back in school, I get a lot of time with Mom! I don't have to go in that crate too often!

So far, I've been great with dogs my size and smaller dogs, we aren't sure about cats, because we don't have any. Mom thinks I would probably be OK, but could possibly need some correction.

When we go on car rides, I ride VERY well. In fact, I usually lay down and go to sleep!

If you want to know more about me, ask Mom, she knows a lot about me!

Hi! My name is Sheldon and I'm looking for something called a "family!" My foster mom told me about them and I think it sounds perfect!

I used to live at this place called animal control and it was really noisy and scary there. I hated it because I was locked up for nearly the entire day in a small cage. Sometimes a nice volunteer would take me outside to go potty but there are lots of other dogs there like me and sometimes there wasn't enough time in the day to let everyone out. I tried everything I could think of to get the attention of the visitors to let me out and maybe take me home, but none of it worked.

I was so thankful when my foster mom took me home because I don't have to live locked up and I get to play and I can go outside whenever I want to. I even have foster siblings to play with.

My foster mom says that I am full of love and would make a perfect pet for an active family. I love riding in the car and she says I'm getting better on my leash. I'm very smart and know some basic commands and I can't wait for my family to teach me more. If you have any questions about me or would like to meet me, please fill out an application for me on our website www.savingtailsanimalrescue.org or email my foster mom any questions. heather@savingtailsanimalrescue.org

Thank you for considering a rescue pup like me!

Sheldon & Heather

Gemma is a 4 year old, 45# mountain curr/lab/boxer mix. She is a little shy at first with new people but warms up super quick. She is a smart girl and is also potty trained. She enjoys playing with her doggie toys or having someone throw a ball around in a fenced-in yard for her to chase after.

She is gentle with the 7 year old boy she currently lives with at her foster home and they have a blast playing together. She is a sweet girl, who is a great mix of playful and cuddly and sleeps thru the night. She does well crated while her foster mom is at work for 8-11 hours and enjoys sleeping in a humans bed at night.

She takes treats gently and knows sit. She recognizes her name and responds to it. She also listens to tones of voice very well. She enjoys sniffing around in a fenced yard or in short bursts running in it with a doggie toy.

Although she lives with other dogs at her foster home, she is dog selective and would require very slow intro's. Her ideal home she would be an only dog or paired with a laid back, calmer dog. She would not be a good candidate to take to dog parks. She would be fine going on walks, but will need some leash training. She also requires a fenced in yard, 3-4 foot chain link is fine, she won't jump the fence but does enjoy going out and just sniffing around.

If your looking for a dog to play ball with, cuddle up to a movie, hang out at the house with or take on neighborhood walks, apply for this true gem named Gemma!

Badger has been with us now for three weeks. He has been a joy to have. Badger settled in to our home in no time at all. He is great with our hounds but is NOT small dog safe. He loves to go for walks and is doing really well at not pulling. He still will not go potty on lead but maybe with more time that will change. Once he discovered the dog beds he decided that he kind of liked those. He also enjoys toys, tossing them around in the air and shaking them is Greyt fun. He does not want to share them, but will now allow me to take them from him. He is a very affectionate boy, he loves children, but with very little ones I would keep a close eye on him. 
Badger is a special needs boy, but this problem is not anything life threatening. He has dry eye. This is in his right eye and only takes 5-10 minutes 3x a day to take care of. He is very good when this is being done. He will crate easily and does enjoy sleeping in the bedroom with you at night. Storms do not seem to bother him. So if your looking for a special boy to add to your family you will absolutely want to meet this handsome boy.

Meet Nikki!

Nikki is a wonderful, sweet, sweet girl who's had a bit of a rough start to life. She is 9 years old, and is just a doll. She is very vocal, and special. Due to her rough start, Nikki can be very skittish for awhile while she warms up to her humans. She does take time and patience. Now that shes warmed up to her foster family, she loves to give some good Roo's and greet them! She loves her two husky foster siblings very much too! Because of her skittishness, a home with small children would not be the best fit for her. She would love a nice, quiet home to live out her life filled with love and patience. She is not cat tested. She does have congenital eye issues most likely since birth, that the Veterinarian does not seem concerned about. She has difficulty with depth perception, but has her vision and has no cataracts or signs of anything that would cause pain or disruption to her life. She just walks a little crooked on walks sometimes, especially if something moves fast and startles her. 
If you are looking for a dog you can create a special bond with, and love and cherish, Nikki is your girl. If you're interested in giving her her furever home, please fill out an adoption application at www.hhshr.com!

Little Tony is an adorable Shih Tzu/Yorkie mix 11 pound boy who is almost 2 years old.  He loves to run and play with the other foster dogs in his temporary home.  His adoption fee includes a crate, training literature, toys, collar, leash and name tag. If interested in Tony, please call 248.344.0181 (no emails!) and leave a message if we are not able to answer at that time. If the dog you are inquiring about is still available, your call will be returned. Thanks so much!

Jet is a gorgeous, playful guy with a big smile!  He is thought to be a Flatcoat Retriever mix (or possibly a Labrador Retriever with a bit of Border Collie thrown in!), just 9-10 mos. old and 43#.  Jet loves to run & play with his foster siblings, and he is the *master* of playing fetch! He is very smart, enjoys learning and listens well; but his previous life didn't include much training, so in addition to what he's learning with his foster family, he would benefit greatly from manners class!  Jet loves every person he meets, and will jump up to give kisses (his foster family is working on this).  Also, Jet's may accidentally knock down littler kids in his excitement to greet them, but would be fine with respectful kids 10+up.  Jet is doing well with crate-training, house training, and walking on a leash too!  Jet's name really fits him -- he is fast and would be great/have a blast at agility classes! Jet's ideal family would be active and provide him with a consistent routine/structure, regular exercise and play/cuddle time to help him really shine!

Tobie is a sweet and spunky little man!  He is apx. 9 y/o and 11#.  He is fully-vetted including a dental, and is heartworm negative. Tobie is a little doll who loves to snuggle on the couch next to his humans.  He enjoys going for a few walks each day, and likes to run & relax in the fenced yard with his foster siblings when the weather is warmer!  He has a great appetite and enjoys treats, and chewing on tiny edible Nylabones!  He also loves playing fetch, especially with squeaky toys, and is great at it!  An ultrasound showed that he has very mild/controlled kidney issues, possibly caused by some type of trauma to his lower back (years ago); this doesn't hinder his movement in any way (see Tobie's video!)  The only result is that he has some reduced ability to sense when his bladder is completely empty. (He has no problem doing his business, he does both types easily and stops peeing when he senses he's "done", but he often "dribbles" once back inside).  He is receiving monthly acupuncture treatments, which seem to be helping to restore his feeling a bit more each visit! :)

Tobie wears a washable belly band (a wide piece of padded fabric around his midsection, easy on/off with velcro) in case of accidents, and he is meticulous about grooming himself.  Our wonderful vet showed us how to gently apply pressure to his lower belly/bladder when he's outside (by wrapping our hands around his lower body and giving a gentle "squeeze") to make sure he is empty.  Tiny Tobie loves baths, and he has one in the sink, quick and easy once a week, to make sure he is extra clean.  He does fine with other dogs, especially those his size; but may chase cats.  Though Tobie is good with respectful kids he has met, an adult home would be his dream! 
He is a spunky little guy, and a perfect mix of snuggly and independent... he would love to be your napping buddy or walking buddy :)

Candy is a beautiful and gentle girl... She is approx. 10 years young, 43#, and is a Lab/Border Collie mix.  Candy was with her human dad since she was a puppy... he recently passed away, and she was lost with nobody else in the world :(   We are honored to have Candy with us at Bark Bark Wag, and her foster family has been working hard to help Candy smile again!  Candy is housebroken and crate-trained (though she absolutely does not need to be crated -- she is an angel!).  Candy has a gentle and polite way about her, and she doesn't ask for much -- she is happy to just spend time with her family.  She knows several commands and loves going for walks -- she doesn't pull and is very gracious on lead. Candy has been fine with the other dogs she has met; cats unknown.  She loves all humans, and is good with respectful kids  (ages 10  & up)...  though we are looking for a calmer, adult home for Candy given the recent loss of her human and the many changes in her life. Candy loves to sleep in her dog bed in the bedroom, or on the humans' bed if invited; her energy level is moderate.  She greets every day with a smile, and has the happiest wag and wigglebutt we've seen in a long time!  Candy would be a dear and comfortable companion for a very lucky family.

Nellie is 5-6 years old, 15#, and thought to be a Poodle mix.  She is a very sweet and affectionate girl, who is looking for a very special type of forever family. Nellie is very fearful of strangers to the point she will "shake in her boots" and hide. She needs to meet a person several times to be comfortable with them. Once she is, she loves to be on your lap and get belly rubs.

Nellie is a stay-at-home kind of girl who doesn't enjoy traveling/car rides, meeting new people or going for long walks (she is starting to enjoy shorter walks in the fenced yard to build her confidence).  Nellie is looking for an adult family who spends a lot of time at home and has a moderate energy level. She has done great with children, though a family who only has them visit would be best...  a lot of activity with kids coming and going makes her nervous.  Nellie has become very attached to her foster mom, and will follow her anywhere; so a woman is most likely to be her new best friend.  Nellie is house-trained and crate-trained; she spends most of her day free-roaming in her foster home, and has not been crated when no one is home, she is not destructive in any way. 

Nellie's prospective family will need to meet her at least twice in her present foster home; please do not apply for Nellie if you can't commit to a slower "getting-to-know-you" period prior to adoption.  Nellie will need a loving, patient family who is willing to let her be the dog she is, and not push her to meet new people or go on outings; allowing her to build confidence at her own pace. She is smart and takes treats gently, food snacks may be the way to her heart when teaching new things.  Nellie is a very quiet, sweet, and loving girl who would also benefit from a very "friendly/socially confident with people" dog companion, who is a mellow, gentle player.  Nellie enjoys snuggling with and hanging out with a best dog friend, as well as with her human family!

*WE NEED AN ADOPTION APPLICATION TO START THE PROCESS*

Dustin is a sweet 2-year-old boy who loves to be cuddled. He knows 'sit' so far, loves treats, and is crate-trained/housebroken.  Dustin came from a home who left him and his 2 fur siblings/fur mom behind in a rural area when they moved :( (He and his mom/siblings all get along great)!  Dustin does best with female dogs of his own size, but tends to be hesitant or fearful meeting new dogs, especially males or larger dogs; he isn't quite sure about (or interested in) cats. Dustin walks on a leash nicely and doesn't pull, but he is also not confident on a leash since he has had very little to no practice. Dustin clearly loves people/kids and enjoys living with a family; he has been great with respectful children 10+up.  He does well in his foster family's fenced yard, but will bark at dogs who approach the fence.  Dustin loves everyone he meets and would love to just be someone's snuggle buddy and walking companion once he has gained more confidence about going on outings.  Dustin would thrive with a loving family who will work with him, and give him new experiences to help build his confidence.  He would be most comfortable as an only dog (or to be adopted with one of his siblings who he is already used to -- Shayla and Daisie will be listed soon!).

Adorable Amelia is thought to be a mix of Mastiff and Boxer.  She is 10# and 9 weeks old as of 4/12/18!  Pupvana.com's puppy calculator predicts that Amelia and her 2 siblings will be 60-75 lbs. at 1 year of age.  Though she is a typical playful pup, Amelia is the most sensitive of her siblings; she has a gentler, more thoughtful way about her.  She is so sweet -- she loves to be held, and will tuck herself into your arms for a good snuggle. These kids are healthy, inquisitive and playful pups! All are working on crate and housetraining, and learning about the all sights & sounds in their foster home :) Adoption preference will be given to families who plan to attend puppy manners classes with their new puppy!

This joyful little bundle is Trixie!  She is apx. 3 years old, 17#; and we believe her to be a Beagle/Toy Fox Terrier mix.  Trixie is a super-sweet girl who loves to cuddle.  Even though she is really fast when running & playing, she is generally a calmer girl.  Trixie enjoys the company of other dogs for playing or naptime, but we don't know if she likes cats or not.  She loves being with her people, and adores sleeping in the humans' bed every chance she gets!  Trixie is housebroken and crate-trained.  She loves playing outside and enjoys walks, but car rides make her a little nervous and she will hide her face.  Trixie's perfect home will have a physical fenced yard so she can run and play, and a similar-sized canine playmate would really make her day (but this is not mandatory).  She would love a family who loves to snuggle and spend time playing with her -- she has so much love to give!

Jade is a beautiful brown color with light eyes; she is 3-4 years old, 38-40# and believed to be a mix of Chocolate Lab and a smaller breed (or two)!  She is a sweetheart, and is friendly with everyone she meets.  Jade loves to be with her people, no matter what they are doing.  She is crate-trained, housebroken, and loves to go for walks! Jade will also join in a game of fetch, and enjoys playing with toys or a nice cuddle on the couch. She does well with other dogs her size (she is a little too rowdy/action-packed with smaller dogs); and has done fine with less playful adult cats who are used to dogs. She has been good with kids in her foster home 10+ up; she may be fine with slightly younger kids too.  Jade is an easy keeper who just goes with the flow.  Jade was heartworm positive, and has been treated while in foster care with us.  She is in the post-treatment stage, where she needs 6 weeks of low activity and some crate rest, which would give her new family plenty of time to bond with her, cuddle on the couch watching movies, etc.  Once this rest period is over, her new family can expect a loving girl who will go for short (or long!) walks, or just enjoy some outside time playing fetch and soaking up the sun. Jade knows "sit" so far, walks well on a leash, and is very treat- motivated; she is a smart girl and would love to learn more with a loving forever family!

Duffy is an adorable, 8 lb, 6 year old toy poodle mix and is looking for his forever family.  
He will do best without small children and large pets.

He is accustomed to spending a lot of time with his people, sitting on their laps, but loves to play with his toys and romps around the yard.

He is neutered, vaccinated, micro-chipped and recently had his teeth cleaned.
If you would like little Duffy to become your new companion please email lesannpayne@yahoo.com or kmwrob@aol.com for an application

Adoption fee $325 to defray the cost of his vet bills.

Rocky is a friendly, affectionate, male/neutered 11 month old purebred Doberman. He is looking for a special home with a family who understands Dobermans, especially when they're young (lots of energy). He'd love a large-sized female dog playmate. No children under 12 as he is too big and doesn't fully understand his size and strength.

Ideal family will have Doberman experience..

New owners must agree to attend obedience classes with this happy boy.

UTD on vaccines, heartworm, neutered and is micro-chipped.

Adoption fee $475.00

description.$t:
Meet Winnie! Sheâs a Jack Russell Terrier Mix who weighs in at approximately 14lbs. She is just a little over 7 years old. Winnie was rescued just days before Christmas from the shelter. She was sadly part of a neglect case where the previous owner had stopped feeding her. She was only let out of her small crate to roam the streets to find food, even in the freezing cold. Even though she was neglected, sheâs the sweetest dog. Sheâs very mild mannered, comes when you call her name and can sit! She loves to play fetch and tug of war. Sheâs also a big cuddle bug who is always near her foster mom. 

That being said, Winnie does have some mild anxiety when left alone, she doesnât not like to be crated and is not 100% potty trained yet. She is looking for a quiet, loving home with another dog friend for her to play with. Sheâs also can be a little skittish, so a home with older children or no children is best. Winnie also has epilepsy and will require her new home to give her medication two times a day and to have regular bloodwork done to ensure her medication is working. If youâd like to meet Winnie please email Wag because she will not be there every weekend. 

Winnie is spayed, microchipped, dewormed, on heart worm and flea preventative, and up to on her vaccines.

Winnie may not be at our adoption events but his Foster Mom is available for "meet and greets" during the week. If interested in Winnie, please fill out an application. 

Our adoption fee is $250.00 (cash or credit card)

This sweetheart will be at the Livonia PetSmart on Saturdays from 11-3. Come up and meet this cutie. The Livonia PetSmart is located at South East corner Middlebelt and I-96 at 13150 Middlebelt Rd Livonia, MI 48150. It is located in the back of the Meijer and Costco Parking lot. Our pets are in the back right hand side of the store past the grooming and vet clinic.  We ask that you DO NOT contact PetSmart about our animals. They are kind enough to provide space for our adoption events, but are not involved with our rescue work. Please email us if there is a specific puppy/dog you would like to meet to be sure they will be at the adoption event.


If you would like to apply for this dog or any of our other dogs, please request an application by clicking the "Adopt Me" or "Contact This Organization" button or email waganimalrescue@yahoo.com.

 Or you can go to our web page at WagAnimalRescue.com  an click the Adopt  to fill out an application. http://waganimalrescue.com/dog-application/

Or email all 21 questions listed below with detailed answers to waganimalrescue@yahoo.com

The information that you provide on the application will help us determine whether the dog that you have chosen is a good match for you so please give as much detail as possible. You must be at least 25 years old to apply. Please answer all questions; otherwise your pre-application may not be reviewed. Include the following information in your email:

1. Your name, address, home phone number & email address. How long have you lived at present address?

2. Age of applicant? Age of co-applicant? Do you live with your parents?

3. Your reason for wanting to adopt this dog? Are you adopting for yourself, family, others, gift/surprise, hunting, watch dog, childâs pet, companion?

4. Type of housing you live in (own home, apartment, condo, mobile home, etc.). If you rent please provide the name of the complex and landlord's phone number.

5. Is your yard Completely Fenced, Partially Fenced, Not Fenced or you have No Yard? How high is your fence? What type of fence: Chain Link, Privacy Fence, Invisible Fence, Other? If no fence, how do you plan on keeping your dog contained in the yard?

6. Number of adults and children in the home, and the ages of the children? Relationship of adults? (Married, Fiance, Older-Children, Roommate , Parent , Other ) Are all household members in agreement with adopting this pet?

7. What arrangements have you made to care for the pet in case you can no longer do so?

8. The number of hours per day the animal will be left alone, and where you will keep the animal when left alone?

9. How much time do your current/previous pet spend outdoors? How much time would this new pet spend outdoors? Where will this dog be routinely living?

10. A list of any animals you've had in the last 10 years, including how long you had them and where they are now. Please include the names of each animal, and the type of animal. 

11. Are/were they spayed/neutered? Current on vaccines? On heartworm prevention (dog)?

12. The name and PHONE NUMBER of current or prior veterinarians in the past 5 years. We will be contacting your veterinarian as a reference. Please contact your vet clinic and give them permission to release your pets information. Are the pets listed under your name, if not please list name pet is listed under?

13. The average cost per for providing preventive veterinary care is $200.00 - $500.00. Additionally there are expenses of food, toys, grooming, boarding, emergency veterinary care, etc, does your household budget allow you to comfortably cover these expenses?

14. How do you plan on exercising this dog? 

15. Are you willing to enroll this dog in obedience training? If no, what are your plans for training this dog?

16.Rescue animals require time to adjust to their new home. Are you willing to give this animal adequate time for proper adjustment - perhaps three weeks or more? What amount of time do you consider to be reasonable for adjustment?

17. Would you object to someone for WAG Animal Rescue coming/calling your home to check on the dog?

18. What behaviors would you be unable to tolerate from an adopted dog? (potty accidents; jumping up on furniture; playing in early am hours; barking; getting into garbage cans; counter surfing; getting on furniture; hiding from guests/other family members; shedding hair on furniture/clothes; chewing; escaping; fighting; digging.)

19. Methods I plan to use to discourage unwanted behavior(s): (Yell; put dog in another room; remove problem item(s); put dog in crate; put dog outside; I will not tolerate bad behavior; swat/spank/hit with newspaper; spritz with water; throw something at dog; who cares dog are dogs.)

20.You understand that rescue dogs may have unknown medical history/problems and/or unknown behavior issues?

21. Additional information you would like to provide to WAG: 


The above information that I have provided to WAG Animal Rescue for the purpose of adopting an animal is accurate and complete.Please put in subject line the name of the animal you are interested in.

IMPORTANT PLEASE NOTE THE FOLLOWING:
A volunteer will review your application and contact you ONLY if you are approved or if further clarification is required. We will make every attempt to contact approved applicants within 5 business days of application submission (M-F), but this will depend on the number of applications received. Please be patient while we processes your adoption applications. We want to be sure that the best match possible is made, so that the dog does not end up needing re-homing again.Please understand that by answering the questions does not guarantee the adoption of the pet, nor are you obligated to adopt the pet.

WAG Animal Rescue adopts to homes that are best fits for our animals' needs, and not on a first-come, first-served basis. If you currently own a dog or have a history of dog ownership, you must provide a vet reference for your application to be processed. Preference is given to applications with prior dog experience and vet references. We are an all-volunteer organization, and regret that we do not have the resources to contact applicants that are not approved. Thank you for your understanding and cooperation.

Approved applicants are based on best fit, not first submitted. WAG RESERVES THE RIGHT TO REFUSE ANY APPLICANT, so please understand that it is within our discretion to make those decisions on behalf of our animals. Keep in mind that we depend 100% on volunteers, most of whom have full-time jobs, so we ask for your understanding as we do the best we can in the endless effort to find homes for these deserving animals!

WE DO NOT HAVE A SHELTER, ALL OF OUR ANIMALS ARE IN ONE OF OUR VOLUNTEERS HOME.

Many WAG's animals are available for viewing and adoption every Saturday from 11 am-3 pm at the Livonia PetSmart, located at Middlebelt and I-96.WE CANNOT GUARANTEE THAT THE RESCUE YOU ARE INTERESTED IN WILL BE AT THE ADOPTION EVENT.


Please remember.......our first and ONLY consideration is the safety and happiness of our dogs.

THANK YOU FOR YOUR INTEREST IN A RESCUE DOG!

For more information about WAG Animal Rescue, adopting an animal or about our fees please visit our home page www.waganimalrescue.com

 For any question please email us at waganimalrescue@yahoo.com

description.$t:
Meet Rico 2, an approximately 1 year old Chihuahua mix, owner surrender. He's about 7 lbs right now and could stand to put on another pound.

Rico is an adorable little guy who loves to cuddle! He is hand shy at first but once he's had some time to adjust to you he'll be your best friend forever! He loves cuddling on the couch with his foster mom and snuggling under the blankets when it's time to go to bed. Rico will need a family who is patient and willing to work with a pup who's instincts have him hiding under the bed instead of running up to greet friends and neighbors. For this reason, Rico would not do when in a home with children under the age of 8.

Rico is not fully house trained and we are working on this. He does not do well in a crate but has not showed any destructive tendencies when left to roam the house while his foster mom is away. Rico would benefit greatly from having a fenced in yard, although this is not required. Rico is fostered with other dogs and does well with them but would benefit from a slow introduction given his timid nature.

Rico is currently up to date on vaccines,  heartworm & flea preventative and dewormed. He is scheduled to be fixed and microchipped prior to adoption.

Our adoption fee is $250.00 (cash or credit card)

description.$t:
Doesnât he have the sweetest face and tender brown eyes! 

Sweeney is just a small fella (13 lbs.) with the perfect combination of spunk and love. We think he is a Chihuahua/Beagle mix.   He is crate trained and will go in his crate when asked. Walks very good on a leash in his harness but can sometimes frightens with sirens or loud cars.  His favorite spot is near you or on your lap. You would never guess that he is nine years old (Chihuahuas can live as long as 20 years).  He can be shy at first but will come out of his shell quickly, especially when a squeaky toy is involved.  

Sweeney is dog selective and can be a bit bossy with other dogs.  He would prefer to be your only lap dog.  Young children can make Sweeney nervous.  A forever home with older (12 or older) or no kiddos would be best. 

Sweeney lost both of the humans he loved within two years of each other.  He soon found himself in an animal shelter. It was determined that Sweeney had luxating patellaâs of both of his knees.  But WAG came to his rescue and had surgery on both of his knees February 7th this year.  He also had his teeth cleaned is doing great.  


Chihuahua/Beagle Mix
Black w/Tan
9 years old on January 1
13 pounds

You must be at least 25 years old to apply. Please answer all questions; otherwise your pre-application may not be reviewed. Include the following information in your email:

1. Your name, address, home phone number & email address. How long have you lived at present address?

2. Age of applicant? Age of co-applicant? Do you live with your parents?

3. Your reason for wanting to adopt this dog? Are you adopting for yourself, family, others, gift/surprise, hunting, watch dog, childâs pet, companion?

4. Type of housing you live in (own home, apartment, condo, mobile home, etc.). If you rent please provide the name of the complex and landlord's phone number.

5. Is your yard Completely Fenced, Partially Fenced, Not Fenced or you have No Yard? How high is your fence? What type of fence: Chain Link, Privacy Fence, Invisible Fence, Other? If no fence, how do you plan on keeping your dog contained in the yard?

6. Number of adults and children in the home, and the ages of the children? Relationship of adults? (Married, Fiance, Older-Children, Roommate , Parent , Other ) Are all household members in agreement with adopting this pet?

8. The number of hours per day the animal will be left alone, and where you will keep the animal when left alone?

9. How much time do your current/previous pet spend outdoors? How much time would this new pet spend outdoors? Where will this dog be routinely living?

15. Are you willing to enroll this dog in obedience training? If no, what are your plans for training this dog?

18. What behaviors would you be unable to tolerate from an adopted dog? (potty accidents; jumping up on furniture; playing in early am hours; barking; getting into garbage cans; counter surfing; getting on furniture; hiding from guests/other family members; shedding hair on furniture/clothes; chewing; escaping; fighting; digging.)

19. Methods I plan to use to discourage unwanted behavior(s): (Yell; put dog in another room; remove problem item(s); put dog in crate; put dog outside; I will not tolerate bad behavior; swat/spank/hit with newspaper; spritz with water; throw something at dog; who cares dog are dogs.)

20.You understand that rescue dogs may have unknown medical history/problems and/or unknown behavior issues?

Cats are of interest to him but it would be best to have him in a home without cats since he plays very actively. He is best in a home with children over 8. He's crate and house trained now. He a very happy pup and just as sweet as can be. 

Rico is neutered, microchipped, dewormed, on heart worm and flea preventative,  and up to on his vaccines. If your interested please fill out an application.

description.$t:
Zous is a spry, loving little guy who is about 14 years old and he's looking for a home to retire in. Zous is house and crate trained, and will use pee pads if available. Zous is good with animals of all sizes (he has a crush on the american bulldog he lives with!) and he walks well on leash. He's a gentle old man, even with dog friendly children but he really loves a lap to curl up in or another pup to snuggle with. Zous does have a heart murmur but it doesn't slow him down. Zous is up to date on vaccines, heartworm preventative and flea and tick preventative.

description.$t:
Penelope is a gorgeous 5yr old, black and white, female Shih Tzu.  She is up to date on vaccines, microchipped, heartworm negative, spayed and has had dental done.  She is housetrained and peepad trained.

Penelope enjoys the outside and will require a fenced yard.  She enjoys other dogs and is good with cats.  Spending time with her family and snuggling on the couch is a favorite of hers.  She does well with children aged 6 years and up.  

She recently has had a litter of pups and is slowly losing her baby weight.  She currently weighs approx 10.5 lb.  She is looking forward to leaving the breeding scene and being a spoiled baby herself.  She so deserves it!  She is such a fun loving, affectionate, girl....?  So if you have room in heart and home for this sweet girl, please fill out an application.

Our adoption fee is $250.00 (cash or credit card)

 Or you can go to our web page at WagAnimalRescue.com  an click the Adopt  to fill out an application. http://waganimalrescue.com/dog-application/

Or email all 21 questions listed below with detailed answers to waganimalrescue@yahoo.com

The information that you provide on the application will help us determine whether the dog that you have chosen is a good match for you so please give as much detail as possible. You must be at least 25 years old to apply. Please answer all questions; otherwise your pre-application may not be reviewed. Include the following information in your email:

1. Your name, address, home phone number & email address. How long have you lived at present address?

2. Age of applicant? Age of co-applicant? Do you live with your parents?

3. Your reason for wanting to adopt this dog? Are you adopting for yourself, family, others, gift/surprise, hunting, watch dog, childâs pet, companion?

4. Type of housing you live in (own home, apartment, condo, mobile home, etc.). If you rent please provide the name of the complex and landlord's phone number.

5. Is your yard Completely Fenced, Partially Fenced, Not Fenced or you have No Yard? How high is your fence? What type of fence: Chain Link, Privacy Fence, Invisible Fence, Other? If no fence, how do you plan on keeping your dog contained in the yard?

6. Number of adults and children in the home, and the ages of the children? Relationship of adults? (Married, Fiance, Older-Children, Roommate , Parent , Other ) Are all household members in agreement with adopting this pet?

7. What arrangements have you made to care for the pet in case you can no longer do so?

8. The number of hours per day the animal will be left alone, and where you will keep the animal when left alone?

9. How much time do your current/previous pet spend outdoors? How much time would this new pet spend outdoors? Where will this dog be routinely living?

10. A list of any animals you've had in the last 10 years, including how long you had them and where they are now. Please include the names of each animal, and the type of animal. 

11. Are/were they spayed/neutered? Current on vaccines? On heartworm prevention (dog)?

12. The name and PHONE NUMBER of current or prior veterinarians in the past 5 years. We will be contacting your veterinarian as a reference. Please contact your vet clinic and give them permission to release your pets information. Are the pets listed under your name, if not please list name pet is listed under?

13. The average cost per for providing preventive veterinary care is $200.00 - $500.00. Additionally there are expenses of food, toys, grooming, boarding, emergency veterinary care, etc, does your household budget allow you to comfortably cover these expenses?

14. How do you plan on exercising this dog? 

15. Are you willing to enroll this dog in obedience training? If no, what are your plans for training this dog?

16.Rescue animals require time to adjust to their new home. Are you willing to give this animal adequate time for proper adjustment - perhaps three weeks or more? What amount of time do you consider to be reasonable for adjustment?

17. Would you object to someone for WAG Animal Rescue coming/calling your home to check on the dog?

18. What behaviors would you be unable to tolerate from an adopted dog? (potty accidents; jumping up on furniture; playing in early am hours; barking; getting into garbage cans; counter surfing; getting on furniture; hiding from guests/other family members; shedding hair on furniture/clothes; chewing; escaping; fighting; digging.)

19. Methods I plan to use to discourage unwanted behavior(s): (Yell; put dog in another room; remove problem item(s); put dog in crate; put dog outside; I will not tolerate bad behavior; swat/spank/hit with newspaper; spritz with water; throw something at dog; who cares dog are dogs.)

20.You understand that rescue dogs may have unknown medical history/problems and/or unknown behavior issues?

We want to be sure that the best match possible is made, so that the dog does not end up needing re-homing again.Please understand that by answering the questions does not guarantee the adoption of the pet, nor are you obligated to adopt the pet.

WAG Animal Rescue adopts to homes that are best fits for our animals' needs, and not on a first-come, first-served basis. If you currently own a dog or have a history of dog ownership, you must provide a vet reference for your application to be processed. We are an all-volunteer organization, and regret that we do not have the resources to contact applicants that are not approved. Thank you for your understanding and cooperation.

Approved applicants are based on best fit, not first submitted. WAG RESERVES THE RIGHT TO REFUSE ANY APPLICANT, so please understand that it is within our discretion to make those decisions on behalf of our animals. Keep in mind that we depend 100% on volunteers, most of whom have full-time jobs, so we ask for your understanding as we do the best we can in the endless effort to find homes for these deserving animals!

description.$t:
Karma is a darling 4lb chihuahua that is around 10 years old.  She is looking for a quiet home that she can live out her golden years in.  Karma is timid at first, but once she warms up she is eager for attention.  She does not do well around children and would be most comfortable in an adult home.  She gets along well with other dogs and cats.  She is house and crate trained.  

Karma is spayed, just had a dental, microchipped, dewormed, on heart worm and flea preventative,  and up to on her vaccines. If you are interested please fill out an application.

Our adoption fee is $125.00 (cash or credit card)

description.$t:
4/18/2018

Daisy is an adorable 9 week old puppy that has a sister named Lily. We believe she is a Lab/Pit Bull mix, but we're not exactly sure. We think she's half cute and half adorable! Daisy loves attention and to play. She likes to give kisses and craves attention! She is learning her manners right now and is very much an active puppy.

Lily and Daisy are bundles of cuteness that spend hours chasing each other around and exploring the big new world. We believe they will be at least 50lbs full grown, but we're not exactly sure. They would do best with another active dog to help burn off some of their puppy energy. They are at the chewing stage so caution needs to be taken in making his environment safe. They are not house trained so will need someone willing to train them. They will need to go outside many times a day; about every half hour. 

Their new home will REQUIRE A PHYSICAL FENCED yard. Please no apartments or condos. Because of their size they would do best in a home without small children under the age of 6. They would not do well being locked up for 8 or more hours a day. They need a home with someone willing to enroll them in training courses. They are fostered with other dogs and they do great with them. 

Daisy is up to date on vaccines, dewormed, on flea & heartworm preventative and is micro-chipped. 

Our adoption fee is $250.00 (cash or credit card)

Please review the listing in FULL and don't click on the inquire or apply button on petfinder.   We don't utilize that feature.   Gyspy is available in southeastern Michigan within 1 hour of zip code of 48164.

If you would like to apply to adopt her, please visit our website listed below.

Gypsy is a sweet little gem that's shy to start but fun to love.   She's a 13 week old Bassador (Bassett Hound/Lab Mix).  She is crate training and doing great.  She was from a "side of the road" litter that was ditched off when the owner wouldn't pay the surrender fee to make sure they were safe in a local shelter.  She hails a Saints flag and is straight from New Orleans, but hasn't batted an eyelash about coming to live and play in Michigan snow.   She likes it here!

She has a longer hound type tail and when she wags - - her whole body wags and she whacks her tail off her own side like a drum in excitement.   She's shy when picked up but when snuggled holds on tight and giives the sweetest neck snuggles as she finds her comfort.   

Her outside potty skills are perfection!  She barely takes steps away from you before her doing her business and then is quickly asking if it's okay if she plays since she's done what we expected.   

If you're willing to let her warm up for just a quick few minutes, you'll be surprised at her "I know you" personality and love.  


Gypsy's adoption fee is $300. 

All dogs are up-to-date on age appropriate vaccines. All dogs  over 6 months of age are spayed/neutered and Heartworm tested prior to adoption. Puppies under 6 months of age are adopted out on spay/neuter contracts and must be fixed before 6 months of age.

If you are interested in meeting and possibly adopting this great dog, please email adopt.nolalabrescue@gmail.com to request an adoption application (or download a copy from our website www.nolalabrescue.org), complete, save it for your reference and send to adopt.nolalabrescue@gmail.com.

PLEASE NOTE: We do not have a shelter where you can view our available dogs. All of our dogs live with foster families in private homes. You must complete an application and references will be checked by a volunteer before you can meet the dog. Please visit our website: www.nolalabrescue.org to learn more about our adoption procedures.

If you are interested in meeting and adopting Skylor, please do NOT click the Petfinder Inquiry button - we would much rather our adopters visit our website, read our adoption requirements and process and apply using our application.

Skylor is available for adoption within 1 hour of 48164.

Skylor is a 5 year old pure-bred (not papered) German Shepherd who came to us from Louisiana as a heart worm positive owner surrender.  His owner was quite elderly and couldn't handle the 86# giant he is.   

He's actually quite gentle and easy going, but if you are in your eighties, it's understandable how he wasn't easy for her.   He knows some basic commands and is crate trained but frankly after 6 months of crate time during most of the day (his heartworm treatment time), he'd much rather have a home where he doesn't have to crate - he's only had to crate with us as "activity restrictions required".   He is house trained very well and has never had an accident.   He sleeps in bed with our kennel manager at night and his best friend is very senior blind poodle.  He gets along with most dogs in our home, but doesn't seem to really care for the energetic ones and tells us so.

He's good on a leash and great in home, though he did attempt to counter surf for goodies a few times but was immediately corrected to "off" from the counter and doesn't seem to do it anymore.  

He will sleep right in front of your door when he's tired as he doesn't want to miss someone coming in, but he doesn't really bark much and does really well with people of all sizes, including toddlers.   

After being with us for 6 months, we are sure we will shed tears when Skylor finds his own forever home, but we are more than sure he deserves his own family and his own attention.    

He's heartworm negative (tested in April), up to date on vaccines, microchipped and neutered.  

He's an easy pick if you have no other animals and don't want to have to do house training or leash training, etc.  He's move in quality, but of course if there are other animals, we'd want to be sure it's a good match for him.  

We look forward the best-fit adoption application for our  sweet Sky!!  


Skylor's adoption fee is $300.

NOT FOR ADOPTION - BREED INFO ONLY!!!!!!!!--------------------------------------------------------------------------------If you see a dog like this, it is most likely an "American Eskimo Dog".  Some call them "Spitz", but that term  refers to a type of dog which can generally be identified by a tail that curls over its back.  Included in the spitz category would be the American Eskimo Dog, Husky, Keeshond, German Spitz and Pomeranian, just to name a few.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  American Eskimo Dogs tend to be reserved on first meeting, then become velcro, cuddle bunnies, lap doggies, glue...you get the idea.  They are intelligent, loving, devoted to their people, and love to be with you.  They generally live 15+ years and tend to be much more active and healthy into later years than some other breeds.  They are fun, playful, and LOVE to run!! Most require a fenced yard or the opportunity to run (safely) off leash on a daily basis.  They are watch doggies in that they will bark as arrivals or strange noises outside, alerting the family to trouble.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  "Eskies", their common nick name, come in 3 sizes:  standard, mini and toy.  Although it is determined by height (about 9-12", 12-15, 15-19) you can estimate by weight.  Under #10 will be a toy....may be a few pounds heavier but generally NOT more than #13, most MINIs are 10-20# maybe up to #22 at times....and about 20-35# would be a standard.  Some books say they can be up to #40, but most are not, and recent breeding has moved toward smaller, more delicate features.  -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------   Eskies are often confused with Samoyed, which are also a spitz breed but are larger, have a slightly different frame and shape and are more likely to weigh over #40.  I can guarantee that if it weighs #70, it is NOT an eskie!!!---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Eskies do shed, but the better the diet, the more they shed seasonally, but they do shed and if you don't want some hair on the furniture, they are not the breed for you.  Most folks who meet, foster or babysit one fall in love with their natures because they are SO loving and total attention sponges who will suck up for some love at every opportunity.  My male loves to go visiting and make the rounds of everyone in the room.  Also, when you own such a beautiful dog, everyone stops to ask what breed it is, etc.  -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  HOWEVER, this is NOT the breed for everyone.  Some folks adopt one due to beauty alone and do not realize these dogs NEED and DEMAND your time.  They are a strong-minded breed and must be trained firmly, but never harshly.  They do NOT respond to harsh training methods at all and can be ruined by such treatment.  Also, as puppies, then can be little rambo puppies with rockets on their feet.  I know - I got my first as a puppy and hated him by 4 months!!  They are all go go go active bouncing zooming puppy who LOVES to chew and get in all sorts of trouble. If you don't find something for puppy to do, or leave him alone too long, puppy will make it s own games and you will NOT like them.  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------So, please DO NOT ADOPT an eskie just because they are gorgeous.  They can become wonderful, devoted and loving companions, but they are a handful as puppies....much more so than some other breeds.  Eskies are very puppish and I don't consider them adults until 3+ years, and they also do not get their full adult coat until then.  So,you may want to consider an excellent, playful, puppyish young one over a puppy, unless you do research and really know what you are getting in to.  That is why so many end up in pounds at 6 months to a year - folks who adopted them and have no patience, time or understanding of how to train them and turn them into excellent adults.  I myself prefer eskies that are 3+ and 5 is a wonderful age!!!! ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Remember that eskies can live very healthy lives past 15+....some 18 years, so don't overlook the seniors out there!  I 've seen 14-15 year olds who bop all around, love walks, dance emphatically for treats, etc.

This boy is a beautiful brindle boy with good energy. He loves to play but can settle down quick for some snuggles and a nap. He LOVES people and forgets sometimes that he isn't a tiny lap dog. He LOVES balls and walks well on a leash. He is eager to learn and is very treat motivated. He gets along better with female dogs but would do best as an only pet with an active mom or dad that can help him continue to be the best boy ever. Does this sound like the perfect match? Please say yes....

Hi I'm Aristotle aka Max and I was born 3/2017.  I am a really good boy as you can see!

I am already crate and potty trained. I love kids, other dogs and should be fine with cats with proper introduction. I'm a silly boy and love to play with my FURsiblings. I am very active so I would love an active family that would take me on long walks. I love to give kisses and get my luvins!

My medical is all done: I'm UTD with my vaccines, neutered and microchipped. I am ready to go as you can see! 

What are you waiting for? Please fill out an adoption application on http://providingforpaws.org/adoption-and-foster-forms.html and mention ME Aristotle...the cute adorable little boy!

Look at this hunk: Titan is a gentle giant. 

He's about 70lbs and believes that he can fit in your lap. He's very sweet and loving. His favorite thing to do is cuddle up or play ball in the yard. Titan is a young adult, born sometime in 2013. Old enough to be out of the "I'm gonna tear up the house stage", but young enough to love life and all that it has to offer. Because he is so big, and has a tendency to want to rough house, we recommend kids 10 and up.  If you are looking for a boy who wants to play, this is your guy!

Titan has been around other dogs and puppies. He likes most dogs he comes across, but can be selective!  He loves a good game, and most kitty's don't appreciate that, so we would recommend a home with out cats.

Titan can be a little shy at first but once he is comfortable he's a very playful boy and would be a great addition to any family. Titan is a very big dog and loves to burn off his energy with a run or lots of play!

If you're looking for an oversized cuddle bug, then Titan is your boy. He is fully vaccinated, micro-chipped, neutered, heartworm tested and on monthly preventative. 

If you can't wait to have Titan as a new family member then please visit http://providingforpaws.org/adoption-and-foster-forms.html to complete an adoption application.

Meet our little wonder Raven!

Raven joined us very emaciated and neglected a last fall and has made so much progress ever since then. She's learning how good life can be. She is eating well and gained some weight. Raven loves her puzzle ball and going for walks.

Raven is said to be around 2-3 years old. She's a very sweet girl and would love have her very own family that spoils her the way she deserves it!

Raven is done with her vaccines, spayed and microchipped. 

If you want to show this sweetheart how great it is to have a loving family to spend the rest of her life with, please fill out an adoption or foster application for RAVEN:

Please contact asap!!

Moose is currently accepting applications from people interests in adopting him. He is 85lbs of pure awesomeness!. Moose wants you to know that he is going to be a little picky about who he chooses as his new family. He would prefer to live in a home without children or cats, even though he can get along with both. He is a big fan of buckwheat pancakes and he loves to watch Duck Dynasty while chewing on his favorite raw hide. He thinks it is funny!! He enjoys sleeping in the bed between his foster mom and dad and he is usually ready to go to bed around 8:30 pm. Moose made it to Safari Animal Rescue after one of their volunteers saved him from going on death row in another shelter. He is a mixed breed of possible coonhound/lab or maybe even Cumberland Spaniel, but without a DNA test, it's hard to tell.  He can sit, go down, shake and he will roll over to get a belly rub. He suffers from some allergies and has to take allergies pills to keep from getting too itchy. He is so happy to see people that he doesn't do well in a wire crate because he has happy tail. Moose needs a back yard to hang out in and he does well with other dogs. His foster home has 4 other dogs and 4 cats too, so he has a lot of company there. He is very loyal and gets attached to people he likes. He has been exposed to numerous dogs and people at his fosters home. Although he enjoys company he is not overly needy or pushy about getting affection and he can be left in the house with his foster sisters and brothers with no problem.

Birthdate: 03/10/2009

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_do:
List of dog breeds

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Jump to: navigation, search
This Chihuahua mix and Great Dane show some of the tremendous variety of dog breeds.

Dogs have been selectively bred for thousands of years, sometimes by inbreeding dogs from the same ancestral lines, sometimes by mixing dogs from very different lines.[1] The process continues today, resulting in a widening in appearance without speciation, "from the Chihuahua to the Great Dane."[2]

The following list uses a wide interpretation of "breed." Breeds are usually categorized by the functional type from which the breed was developed. The basic types are companion dogs, guard dogs, hunting dogs, herding dogs, and working dogs, although there are many other types and subtypes. Breeds listed here may be traditional breeds with long histories as registered breeds, rare breeds with their own registries, or new breeds that may still be under development.

In some cases, a breed's origin overlaps the boundaries of two or more countries; the dog is normally listed only in the country with which it is most commonly associated; for example, by its designated country according to the Fédération Cynologique Internationale (FCI). Some dogs, such as the Löwchen, have an uncertain origin and are listed under several countries.
